subject: Re: [junit] JUnit FAQ TestSetup example
msgSnippet: When using the TestSetup decorator, Implementing oneTimeSetUp() is not absolutely essential, but why would you want to use the test decorator unless
messageBody:
When using the TestSetup decorator, Implementing oneTimeSetUp() is not
absolutely essential, but why would you want to use the test decorator
unless oneTimeSetUp was your aim?

The main point of the TestSetup decorator is to provide the ability to
perform one-time setup and teardown, i.e. oneTimeSetUp() is run once before
all of your tests (not each, but all), and oneTimeTearDown() is run once
after all of your tests complete. If you don't need this functionality,
then you don't need the TestSetup decorator. You may remove the following
code from your suite() method:
TestSetup wrapper = new TestSetup(suite) {
public void setUp () {
oneTimeSetUp();
}
and have it return suite instead of the TestSetup that it currently returns.

Cheers,

_chas_
